title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on the deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for mutual life insurance companies regarding policyholder dividends. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for mutual life insurance companies regarding policyholder dividends. The limitation for any taxable year shall not be less than $35,000,000. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if certain conditions regarding stock ownership are met. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for mutual life insurance companies regarding policyholder dividends. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if certain conditions regarding stock ownership are met. Section 809 of the Code is repealed, and amendments are made to sections 807 and 812 regarding tax-exempt interest. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" makes amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code. It repeals section 809 and makes changes to sections 808, 817, and 842. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994, with an exception for section 809(f) for taxable years before January 1, 1995. Limitation on loss carrybacks for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code: Capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back to taxable years before January 1, 1995. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses as per an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This exemption applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Additionally, there is a sense of Congress regarding the use of increased revenues. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS RELATING TO USE OF INCREASED REVENUES. Congress believes that any revenue increase from this Act should go towards deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children's nutrition, education, housing, and family support.
